Description: Rim and body sherd of small South Ionian pottery mug; interior: glazed with red band lined in white near rim and white band on floor; exterior: reserved upper body, lower part glazed.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The rim and interior slip find parallels with Samian Hera cups. However, unlike Hera cups which have dipinto dedications to the goddess, this cup has no inscription and the fabric is finer. Similar cups have been found in the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and thus this shape is not exclusive to Hera (Schlotzhauer 2012 116). For parallels with Hera cups, see British Museum 1888,0601.401, 1888, 0601.402, 1888.0601.403, and 1888,0601.405. For parallels with another similar mug, but with a graffito inscription, see Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.227.1899.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.892) (phase 3)
